reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Envelope 1: Improve the safe access to quality education and protection services in the camps of Idleb

description.narrative:
Through this 11 months project , Sadad Humanitarian Organization(SHO) is going to improve the safe access of 16,778 displaced children(7625 boys amp 9153 girls)including 186 CwD to inclusive education and protection life-saving services in 25 schools welcoming children from 168 IDPs sites with high severity needs in Dana and Maaret Tamasrin sub-districts by providing a multi-sectorial package of education and child protection services with innovative modalities that best meet the needs of the most vulnerable groups of children under the 1st standard allocation of SCHF 2022 during summer and in the academic year(2022-2023) with protective measures from Covid-19.
In education, the project is going to enhance the safe access of 16,778 displaced children(7625 boys amp 9153 girls)including 186 CwD to quality inclusive education services in protective environment by conducting light repair to 111 classrooms and 50 wash facilities , supplying 25 schools with new furniture and doing maintenance to the old furniture during July amp August and providing formal education services to 14102 children(6263 boys amp 7839 girls) enrolled in formal education in 25 schools using SIG curriculum and non-formal education services to 2676 children(648 OOSC children in catch-up classes using curriculum(B) amp remedial classes to 2028 children are at the risk of drop out and behind in their education using the adopted Syrian curriculum physically with preventive measures of Covid-19, contract with 441 formal and 75 non-formal education teachers and pay their incentives , provide professional development to the teachers and other supporting staff in 25 schools on(Modern Teaching Techniques-Integration of children with disabilities in the education response-Child safeguarding), conduct 25 back to learning campaigns in 25 different locations , procure and distribute 25 sets of teaching materials to 25 schools, print and distribute 2676 copies of(648 copies of curriculum(B)to the children in catch-up classes and 2028 copies of adopted Syrian curriculum to the children in remedial classes), procure and distribute 14750 stationery kits (school bags amp stationery)to 14750 children in 25 schools , provide 25 schools with operational cost (drinkable water - cleaning tools amp materials), conduct training on safety and evacuation for the teachers and children in the 25 schools, conduct monthly PTA/SMC meetings with the parents in 25 schools, provide awareness sessions on Covid-19 and hygiene protocols to the children and caregivers, provide the 25 schools with cleaning and disinfection materials and conduct weekly cleaning as preventive measures of Covid-19, support the mid and end year exams in the 25 schools, conduct ASER and provide awareness sessions to the staff and PTA members on PSEA during the academic year.
In child protection, the project is going to improve the access of 16,300 beneficiaries to quality life- saving Child Protection services through providing structured PSS activities to 3320 children , school-based awareness and outreach activities 14,750(6564 boys amp 8186 girls) children including 186 CwD enrolled in formal and non-formal education in the 25 targeted schools with focus on the new displaced children, female children, children OOSC, CwD and children affected by Covid-19 in addition to awareness sessions on CP issues to 1500 parents and caregivers as well as building the capacity of 50 staff on CP related issues using the appropriate modalities.
The beneficiaries and stakeholders participated effectively in the planning and designing phases of the project where SHO conducted interviews, discussions, meetings, FGDs and surveys and SHO will keep using this participatory accountable approach and will ensure that all the beneficiaries from the different groups can provide their feedback, suggestions and complains through having feedback mechanisms and channels in the schools.
